abstract: Amid JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss at its chief investment office, DealBook highlights some executives who may face additional scrutiny from the embarrassing incident.
snippet: Amid JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss at its chief investment office, DealBook highlights some executives who may face additional scrutiny from the embarrassing incident.

headline.main: Others in the Spotlight After JPMorgan’s Big Trading Loss

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss could give supporters of tighter industry regulation a huge new piece of ammunition as they fight a last-ditch battle with the banks to strengthen the Volcker Rule.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss could give supporters of tighter industry regulation a huge new piece of ammunition as they fight a last-ditch battle with the banks to strengthen the Volcker Rule.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take long for bank reformers to say we told you so.

headline.main: A Shock From JPMorgan Is New Fodder for Reformers

keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)

abstract: JPMorgan Chase disclosed in a regulatory filing that its Chief Investment Office, a group that has come into focus for its proprietary bets, has suffered “significant” paper losses in a portfolio of credit investments.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase disclosed in a regulatory filing that its Chief Investment Office, a group that has come into focus for its proprietary bets, has suffered “significant” paper losses in a portfolio of credit investments.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase, which emerged from the financial crisis as the nation’s biggest bank, disclosed on Thursday that it had lost more than $2 billion in trading, a surprising stumble that promises to escalate the debate over whether regulations need to rein in trading by banks.

headline.main: JPMorgan Discloses $2 Billion in Trading Losses

byline.original: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis

lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Trading Losses Inflame Debate Over Regulation  |  JPMorgan Chase, which emerged from the financial crisis as the nation’s biggest bank, disclosed on Thursday that it had lost more than $2 billion in trading, a surprising stumble that promises to escalate the debate over whether regulations need to rein in trading by banks.

abstract: Stocks finished close to even on Wall Street, although the financial sector declined in the wake of trading losses at JPMorgan Chase.
snippet: Stocks finished close to even on Wall Street, although the financial sector declined in the wake of trading losses at JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: The disclosure that  JPMorgan Chase lost more than $2 billion in trading activities put a damper on the shares of some of the biggest banks on Friday, but there was little more than a ripple through the broader market on Wall Street.

headline.main: Stocks End Little Changed, Despite JPMorgan Loss
headline.print_headline: Shares Little Changed Despite JPMorgan Loss

abstract: The Federal Reserve and Financial Services Authority of Britain have been in discussions with JPMorgan Chase since April about the trading group that on Thursday disclosed more than $2 billion in losses.
snippet: The Federal Reserve and Financial Services Authority of Britain have been in discussions with JPMorgan Chase since April about the trading group that on Thursday disclosed more than $2 billion in losses.
lead_paragraph: United States and British regulators have been in discussions with JPMorgan Chase for almost a month about the trading group that disclosed more than $2 billion in losses on Thursday, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline.main: Regulators Looking Into JPMorgan Trading Activities Before $2 Billion Loss

abstract: Shares in major banks plummeted on Friday amid concern that JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss may portend problems at other institutions.
snippet: Shares in major banks plummeted on Friday amid concern that JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss may portend problems at other institutions.
lead_paragraph: Shares in major banks plummeted on Friday amid concern that JPMorgan Chase‘s $2 billion trading loss may portend problems at other institutions.

headline.main: Bank Stocks Plummet on JPMorgan’s Woes

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: Since disclosing a $2 billion trading loss, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief, has been getting flayed for having been a vocal opponent of the regulatory reform while overseeing risky trades.
snippet: Since disclosing a $2 billion trading loss, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief, has been getting flayed for having been a vocal opponent of the regulatory reform while overseeing risky trades.
lead_paragraph: The news of JPMorgan Chase’s estimated $2 billion loss stemming from a misguided hedging strategy in the bank’s chief investment office has set off a spring-loaded schadenfreude cannon among the industry’s critics.

headline.main: S.E.C. Opens Investigation Into JPMorgan’s $2 Billion Loss

byline.original: By Ben Protess and Susanne Craig

abstract: A seemingly innocent principle from the technology world, Moore’s Law, could be one of the factors that helped JPMorgan Chase’s hedging strategy go awry.
snippet: A seemingly innocent principle from the technology world, Moore’s Law, could be one of the factors that helped JPMorgan Chase’s hedging strategy go awry.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of reasons that JPMorgan Chase had a $2 billion trading loss on a hedging strategy gone wrong — poor oversight, mismanaged risk and poorly constructed defenses.

headline.main: How Moore’s Law Affects Wall St. Trading

abstract: Leading members of Congress demanded that federal regulators strengthen proposed banking rules in the wake of JPMorgan Chase’s disclosures of trading losses.
snippet: Leading members of Congress demanded that federal regulators strengthen proposed banking rules in the wake of JPMorgan Chase’s disclosures of trading losses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Leading members of Congress on Friday demanded that federal regulators strengthen proposed banking rules and scrutinize trading closely in the wake of JPMorgan Chase’s disclosures of trading losses.

byline.original: By John H. Cushman Jr. and Edward Wyatt

abstract: JPMorgan Chase and its chief, Jamie Dimon, have been among the most outspoken opponents of the Volcker Rule, spending significant amounts of both money and time to get their message across.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase and its chief, Jamie Dimon, have been among the most outspoken opponents of the Volcker Rule, spending significant amounts of both money and time to get their message across.
lead_paragraph: The $2 billion trading loss that JPMorgan Chase disclosed late on Thursday provided ample ammunition for supporters of the Volcker Rule, which would restrict government-backed banks’ ability to conduct proprietary trading.
